Description: Terracotta figure plaque of crouching man holding phallus (probably ithyphallic Harpocrates). A mould-made man seated on sloping ground, holding his huge phallus to his left chest, gripping its root with both hands. Some details appear to be hand modelled. The back and the underside of the plinth are flat. Traces of plaster or a white coating by left leg. Micaceous orange-brown Nile silt with a partially drab surface.
Curator's comments: Similar figures of Harpocrates have been found to date to the 5th to 4th century BC. (Torok 1995, pl.34, nos 48-49). Similar pieces were made at Naukratis and elsewhere in the Nile Delta area in this fabric.See figure plaque from Tell el-Muqdam dated to the late 5th century BC (Redmount and Friedman 1997, Fig. 7). Török, L. 1995. Hellenistic and Roman Terracottas from Egypt, Rome. Redmount, C. A. & Friedman, R. F. 1997. Tales of a Delta Site: Preliminary Report on the 1995 Field Season at Tell el-Muqdam. ‘Journal of the American Research Center in Egypt’ 34; 57-83.
On back for figure incised '60' and written 'Naucratis. Eg. Ex. F. 1886".
Bibliographic references: Terracotta / Catalogue of Terracottas in the British Museum (3231)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (DC.094) (Phase 1)
